subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Use of half-letters
msgSnippet: Ron: In the early days of the ablphabet, Kingsley Reed had set up correspondence between English speakers around the world.  Your mention of this reminded me
messageBody:
Ron:

In the early days of the ablphabet, Kingsley Reed had set up
correspondence between English speakers around the world. Your mention
of this reminded me of my own experience with a QS pen pal in Lower
Hutt, New Zealand, and I have just reached into my desk drawer and
pulled out a letter written to me on 6 February 1976 by Harold
Trembath. Harold had a lovely QS hand - very neat and precisely written
- just what you would expect from a retired accountant. Only an
occasional letter or pronunciation would give me pause. I found it
refreshing that some of his accent came through in his writing.

I don't know if this would work today since people are so
computer-oriented, but reading other people's handwritten QS is very
good practice in my opinion. Sir James Pitman mentioned
"ever-circulators" or something to that effect in the prologue to
/Androcles and the Lion/. I believe this term refers to a letter which
is sent round to a number of people, with each person adding to the text
of the letter. In that manner, each person has a chance to read what
everyone else in the group has written and a chance to practice
themselves. There is no reason something like this could not be done
today for reading and writing practice.

Is there anyone in the group who would like to participate in such a
project? You just have to promise to send the letter on its rounds and
not hold it too long in making your contribution to it. The topic of
the letter could be QS and ways to promote it, or anything else that
suits the participants. Drop me an e-mail if you are interested, and I
would be glad to help organize and participate in it.

Paige

Ron Cameron wrote:
> It does seem natural to use the half-letters in these instances. I'm
> still learning Quikscript and my main concern is not falling into bad
> habits. I've been engaged in daily practice for a couple of months
> now and my ability has progressed quite well. The transition from
> Junior to Senior is rather intuitive and I love the look of the text
> as more and more ligatures are possible.
>
> Reading is slower going, of course. It's almost like returning to
> grade school and sounding out words. More daily practice will help, I
> know. As for texts, I've seen quite a bit of things done on the
> computer, but I'd also like to see more handwritten QS from
> experienced writers. I think it could assist us learners in
> developing our own hand.
>
> Thanks for the quick response!
>
> Ron Cameron
>
> ----- Original Message ----
> From: pgabhart <pgabhart@...>
> To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Monday, September 17, 2007 6:24:57 PM
> Subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Use of half-letters
>
> I would use both half-letters you mentioned. I always use a half-pea
> when roe follows it, and it is so easy to move into the half-zoo at the
> end of the et, why wouldn't one use it? Also, you didn't mention the
> possibility of using a half-tea at the end of the word. I probably
> wouldn't use it here -- the right angle change in direction just doesn't
> seem smooth to me, but one certainly could.
>
> But to answer your query, half-letters should certainly be used in the
> middle of words. I would still use a half-pea in the word
> "misrepresent, " for example.
>
> Paige
>
> ronwcameron wrote:
> >
> > Forgive me if this topic has already been covered. I did a brief
> > search of the forum and didn't find anything that specifically
> > addressed the topic.
> >
> > My question regards the use of half-letters within a word. I
> > understand that beginning or ending a word with a half-letter is fine,
> > but is it good style to use them intermedially?
> >
> > For example, in spelling /present/, one could use:
> >
> > half-pea roe et half-zoo utter no tea (half-1, 25, 28, half-12, 36,
> 23, 3)
> >
> > I'm curious how many of you would employ a half-letter in this scenario.
> >
> >
>
>
>
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------

> someone who knows.
> Yahoo! Answers - Check it out.
>

In the early days of the ablphabet, Kingsley Reed had set up

Hutt, New Zealand, and I have just reached into my desk drawer and

computer-oriented, but reading other people's handwritten QS is very

Is there anyone in the group who would like to participate in such a
